urn:contentItem:5RY3-FNM1-DY0W-44CH-00000-00Shutdown Showdown; Mark Zuckerberg Finally Speaks Out; Trade Crackdown; Kidde Smoke Alarm Recall; Police Save Chocking Baby; Toys R Us Liquidation Starts Today; Federal Reserve Raises Rates2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisShutdown Showdown; Mark Zuckerberg Finally Speaks Out; Trade Crackdown; Kidde Smoke Alarm Recall; Police Save Chocking Baby; Toys R Us Liquidation Starts Today; Federal Reserve Raises RatesLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, March 22nd.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the east coast.

"I'm really sorry," Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg finally speaks out over the company's growing privacy scandal calling it a major breach of trust. The fallout for the technology sector as Zuckerberg says he is willing to testify before Congress if necessary.

Meanwhile, the race to avoid a shutdown, lawmakers have reached a tentative agreement on a $1.3 trillion spending bill to keep the government running but do they have the votes? The very latest as Congress scrambles to pass the bill before midnight tomorrow night.

Trade crackdown, President Trump will announce strict tariffs and restrictions on Chinese imports and China investing. That's happening today at noontime; the move sparking concerns over a possible trade war.

I spoke with the director of the White House national trade council, Peter Navarro about what's to come.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL TRADE COUNCIL: This talk like this I think is irresponsible in some sense because if you look at the chess board, I think it's clear that all we want is to defend ourselves against economic aggression. And I see this as bullish for corporate America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Markets under pressure today, take a look. Futures indicating a decline of about 200 points at the start of trading this morning. Stocks settled lower yesterday and that momentum is continuing in a big way this morning. The Nasdaq is down 80 points right now.

The Federal Reserve, of course, raised interest rates yesterday for first time this year under new Chairman Jay Powell. Markets traded down after that. The Dow Industrials closed down 45 points, the S&P was down 5 and the Nasdaq was down 19.

In Europe, stocks are lower right now. Investors are watching and wait for the Bank of England's decision on interest rates. That's due in about an hour from now when we will get you the news as soon as it hits the tape.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances. Japan was up -- rest of the majors were lower but Nikkei average was up 1 percent. Hang Seng in Hong Kong was down 1 percent.

Plus, not playing around, the details as Toys R Us begins to liquidate.

All those stories this morning coming up and joining me to talk all about it: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle, rather; and the "Wall Street Journal's" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman. Great to see you.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here -- thanks.

BARTIROMO: So much on the table to talk about.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: There's a ton and we've got the China sanctions release later today.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we've got restrictions on investment as well as tariffs.

ROSCHELLE: Well, it's both ways, right. It's trade tariffs and perhaps prohibitions on their investment in the U.S.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Fed raised interest rates yesterday -- no big deal, I mean 1.75 percent.

FREEMAN: And the Fed thinks the economy can grow faster and they finally realized that there are people in the economy who can come in to the labor market. So these are good things.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: At the same time those smart gentlemen and ladies down in D.C. are spending that much more money, driving up the deficit that much more in the face of higher interest rates --

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- and a Fed that's winding down its balance sheet and will not stand at the ready to buy the debt that the federal government will be trying to sell.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's right.

We'll coming up this morning, we've got all that on the table. Senate Finance Committee chairman, Orrin Hatch. We'll talk about that coming up. Also, former presidential candidate, Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee is here. Former presidential candidate Herman Cain is joining us. And the host of "VARNEY AND COMPANY" Stuart Varney weighing in as well.

All that coming up this morning.

But first, House Republicans have finally unveiled their whopping $1.3 trillion spending bill ahead of the looming government shutdown. President Trump endorsed the bill last night. He tweeted this, "That $1.6 billion to start wall on southern border, rest will be forthcoming. Most importantly got $700 billion to rebuild our military; $716 billion next year -- most ever of; had to waste money on Democratic giveaways in order to take care of military pay increase and new equipment.

The funding measure needs to make it through the House Rules Committee before a floor vote. Some conservative members in the chamber not happy with this bill -- too much money.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MARK MEADOWS (R), NORTH CAROLINA: We continue to fund sanctuary cities. We continue to fund Planned Parenthood. We don't build the wall but yet we put money in for a tunnel. The last time I checked, when the President was campaigning, he wasn't campaigning for a tunnel between New Jersey and New York. But I'm not very optimistic that there will be conservative wins in this.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Arkansas congressman House Budget Committee chairman, Steve Womack. Chairman Womack -- thanks so much for joining us this morning.

REP. STEVE WOMACK (R-AR), HOUSE BUDGET COMMITTEE: Maria -- it's great to be with you.

BARTIROMO: What about that? Planned Parenthood, sanctuary cities -- all of this extra spending has us looking at trillion dollar deficits 10 years out and beyond -- how do you justify that?

WOMACK: Well look, let's first of all understand what we're doing in this bill and again, this bill is not across the finish line yet but we went into these negotiations with the express intent of primarily fixing our military.

And in order to do that, like any other negotiation, understand that the other side gets a vote in this thing. We don't have 60 votes in the Senate. So in this four corners negotiation, when you've got members of the Senate, the minority leader in the senate, the minority leader in the House and the two majority leaders in the House and Senate on the Republican side negotiating, they're going to get a vote.

So in order to beef up the Defense, there were certain things, other concessions that had to be made and that's just what's going to happen in negotiation.

It's a 2,000-page bill. Members are still sorting through it. We've got a short time line that we're being asked to consider this thing, so there's a lot of activity going on in the nation's capitol today with regard to this omni-package.

BARTIROMO: Look, I understand the need to fund the military and we talk about that all the time, given the fact that our aging fleet in the Navy has 50 percent of the planes unable to even fly. I get all of that. We're seeing accidents.

But did you need to go to that number? Did you need that much in terms of military? Could you have scaled back a bit so that you weren't handcuffed to put all of this other spending on domestic issues?

WOMACK: Well, they wanted dollar for dollar -- Maria. Remember, the Democrats expected dollar for dollar and we didn't go dollar for dollar.

But we took our cues from the leadership in the Pentagon. Secretary Mattis was very emphatic as to the numbers that he needed to hit in order to be able to meet the demands that are created by the threat that is expanding around the globe.

And this is not the time for us to be taking a pass on taking care of our men and women in uniform. We've got fundamental issues in the Pentagon. We've got inner (ph) strength (ph) problems. We've got four structure problems. We've got acquisition program problems.

And we've got an expanding threat around the globe. It was necessary for us to take the steps that we've taken in this bill to beef up our military.

And now, when you do that, you have to make concessions on the other side and while they didn't get dollar for dollar, there were things in that bill, there are things in this bill that we'd prefer not to have to do. But that's what happens when you sit down at the table and have to negotiate the way we do.

BARTIROMO: Mr. Chairman, will you get enough votes for this massive bill?

WOMACK: To be determined. I'm on the Whip team but I'm not aware of the Whip count last night. I know there will be a lot of undecided voters or undecided members. We have a 2,000-page bill to sort through. We know pretty much what's in it from a numbers perspective but what we don't know are some of the other things that have been added onto this bill that are unrelated to the spending provision.

So that's what members will be going through today to try to figure out exactly what else is in the bill and whether they can muster, you know, the votes necessary to be able to put it across the finish line. We still have to go through the rule process and there might be some concerns about whether we can even pass the rule. But sometime today we'll have that in clarity.

BARTIROMO: So is there a plan to face off against trillion dollar deficits? When does that become a priority?

WOMACK: Well look, part of what we've got to do in order to be able to fix the fiscal glide path of this country, we've taken some steps already. We worked on the tax code by lowering tax rates. We think that's part and parcel to try to grow this economy because you're going to have to grow the economy to be able to fix --

BARTIROMO: Right.

WOMACK: -- the deficits and the debt as we know them today.

We've gone after a lot of the over-regulation that happened in the last several years. We're beginning to take steps to be able to rid the private sector of a lot of this over-regulation. But growing this economy has to be a central focal point; a growth model is what's going to fix what ails this country right now. So cutting taxes is doing that, cutting regulations.

And then we eventually are going to have to deal with the elephant in the room and that is the mandatory side of spending, about 70 percent of federal dollars go out to programs that are on auto pilot. And I believe you will see this Congress and the next Congress pivot quickly to doing things that go right to the heart of what's driving the deficits and the debt in this country.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's what I'm saying.

WOMACK: And that's on the mandatory side.

BARTIROMO: That's what I'm saying, sir. I mean at some point it has to become a priority. But now what I hear being talked about is not that, but phase two of the tax cuts.

Here's Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy with me yesterday when I asked him about that, the next step in tax reform.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER: I want to see the individuals made permanent. But like any big bill when you go through it, there are going to be other aspects that you didn't think about. Let's see where we need to go there. Let's see how this bill has transferred and changed the economy.

Is there places we missed? Let's listen to the economy and let's go back and analyze that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What about that, Mr. Chairman? What do you want to see in terms of phase two in the tax cuts?

WOMACK: Well, certainly we'd like to make the individual cuts permanent. And there's no question about that. I mean that's just part of giving certainty to the economy and certainty to American households.

But it's still I think a bit early for us to be able to with clarity understand exactly what this Tax Cut and Jobs Act proposal and law has actually done. I think it will take us for the rest of the year to figure out exactly how it's going to impact businesses, impact families.

And so if there are tweaks that need to be made, we're all in about that.

BARTIROMO: Let ask you --

WOMACK: There was a tweak that we took care of yesterday or at least in the announcement with the grain farmers. So we're going to find out a little bit more about the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act as we move through the year.

BARTIROMO: Mr. Chairman -- I want to ask you about Facebook but before I get to that, I want to read you Governor Mike Huckabee's tweet. He's tweeting that he's going to be on this program. We're going to talk to him in a few minutes after you.

He says "I will be on @MariaBartiromo and will let loose on GOP for collapsing and surrendering to Pelosi and Schumer on a disgusting spending bill. It's not a compromise, it's capitulation. To borrow a phrase from Nancy Reagan, "Just say no". What do you want to say to Mike Huckabee?

WOMACK: Well look, Mike Huckabee's a great friend of mine. I was a mayor in the town of Arkansas when he was my governor. He was my commander in chief.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. But he says the bill is disgusting.

WOMACK: He can say it's disgusting. And that's easy to say from the outside looking in. But as I said before, I believe strongly that we have a mandate to provide for the security of this country. And in order to be able to get the gains that we did for the Pentagon and for the national security apparatus, there were concessions that had to be made.

That's going to happen in any negotiation. You can call it disgusting all day long. And there are things in this bill that I would prefer not to have to vote for. That's why we're sorting through it today to figure out are there any other issues that have popped up in this bill that will make it distasteful enough that we can't support it.

And look, we've got until tomorrow to fix it. If not, we'll be looking at a short-term CR and back to the negotiating table.

BARTIROMO: Mr. Chairman -- what about Facebook and what we have seen. These companies are more powerful than they ever have been.

Zuckerberg -- Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Facebook broke his silence yesterday on the data mining scandal that affected more than 50 million users in a new interview. He hinted of regulation and he said that he's willing to testify. Here's what he said, sir.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: This was a major breach of trust and I'm really sorry that this happened. We need to make sure there aren't any other Cambridge Analyticas out there, right; or folks who have improperly accessed data. So we're going to go now and investigate every app that has access to a large amount of information.

LAURIE SEGALL, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Will you testify before Congress?

ZUCKERBERG: So the short answer is I'm happy to if it's the right thing to do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What kind of legislation would you like to see or not see? Tell me what you're thinking in terms of new regulation coming on technology.

WOMACK: Well, as somebody who pushes back against a lot of federal regulation because I think we he have a lot of it already, I think where it concerns the privacy of people, particularly given Internet and the expanse of the worldwide web and all of the potential problems associated with the stealing of intellectual property and the stealing of personal identity -- those kinds of things, that Congress does have a role in this and Congress must address at a minimum issues that protect the privacy of everyday citizens.

BARTIROMO: So in other words, we will see new regulation, you think?

WOMACK: I think you're going to see some regulation. You're going to see hearings here in Washington and you're obviously going to have a regulatory response to it for sure.

BARTIROMO: Yes. This from people who don't want to see big government but there's clearly an issue here.

WOMACK: Yes. But you have to understand that even though people push back against regulations in general, that doesn't mean we're a no-regulation type body. We just feel like they've got to be smart regulations and I think that Congress will get there.

BARTIROMO: Mr. Chairman -- good to see you this morning. Thanks very much.

WOMACK: Good to see you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching --

WOMACK: All the best.

BARTIROMO: -- the developments today. Chairman Womack there.

Still ahead -- stoking fears of a trade war, President Trump set to announce up to $60 billion in stiff tariffs on Chinese imports and restrictions on Chinese investments. What White House Trade Council director Peter Navarro had to say about the concerns of retaliation.

Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We're looking at markets right now. Markets are expected to open down. We're expecting a 200-point selloff right out of the gate this morning, extending yesterday's losses after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates yesterday by a quarter of a point.

Meanwhile the Trump administration set to announce punitive measures against China today for the country's unfair trade practices. We're expecting tariffs as well as restrictions on investment.

Lauren Simonetti with the details right now and headlines -- Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, we are -- Maria.

And these measures are expected to include those restrictions on China's investments and pretty steep tariffs on Chinese goods. China has been accused of violating intellectual property rights, pressuring U.S. companies to transfer our technology and our trade secrets. The White House National Trade Council director Peter Navarro -- on this show a bit ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NAVARRO: It's an historic day. This is a fundamental shift in American policy towards China after literally decades of economic dialogue. And you know, talk is not cheap with the Chinese. It's actually been very expensive because while we've been talking with them since 2003, they've been robbing our technology blind.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Beijing is expected to retaliate. The "Wall Street Journal" reporting that China is looking to impose tariffs on U.S. agricultural exports like soybeans and hogs. That would target the farm belt and a good part of Donald Trump's base.

Massive recall of smoke detectors -- Kidde calling back about half a million of them because a flaw can interfere with the device's ability to detect smoke. The recall includes Kidde dual sensor smoke detectors sold at retailers including Home Depot, Wal-Mart as well as amazon.com. If you have one of these defective models, please contact Kidde for a free replacement.

And shocking body camera footage shows the crucial moments. An Ohio police officer saved a choking baby. The officers say they saw the baby's mother stop her car in traffic as her two-month-old baby girl had milk clogging her nose and mouth.

That's when the officer jumped into action. He administered back thrusts to eventually clear her airway. The officer said being a dad of four helped him know what to do and the baby girl is ok. Liquidation sales at Toys R Us, they are set to begin today at most of the company's 700 bankrupt stores. Shoppers are looking for bargains. They're being advised to act fast because the popular toys are expected to sell out pretty quickly. The company is hoping inventory is cleared by June. Toys R Us, as you know, fell victim to competition from online retailers but also the discount chains and the debt from a leveraged buyout years ago -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Lauren -- thank you so much.

Coming up, an interest rate hike sending markets lower this morning. Futures indicated down 200 points right now. The aftermath from newly appointed Fed chair Jay Powell's first policy meeting -- that and worries over trade.

Then the best around, "The Karate Kid" dusts off his bandanna for a YouTube original series with a preview of the new take on a classic series, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEROME POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: As you all would now We decided today to raise the target rate for the federal funds rate by one quarter of a percentage point, bring it to 1.75 percent. This decision marks another step in the ongoing process of gradually scaling back monetary policy accommodation, a process that has been under way for several years now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell after the Fed's move to raise interest rates yesterday, first move this year. Markets under pressure this morning on the heels of that after being weaker yesterday as well; not a significant move yesterday but nonetheless on the downside.

Joining us right now to talk more about that Nuveen Asset Management chief equity strategist, senior portfolio manager Bob Doll. Bob -- good to see you.

BOB DOLL, CHIEF EQUITY STRATEGIST, NUVEEN ASSET MANAGEMENT: Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: You were expecting an interest rate hike.

DOLL: Absolutely -- like everybody else.

BARTIROMO: But this market -- you're not a fan? What?

DOLL: Neutral. I think we're in a trading range. We're going to flop around here. Maybe the high in 2875 in January and the low 2532 and the correction -- that could be the measure we have for months to come. We're just going to bounce around.

ROSCHELLE: So if you're an investor and you're watching the show, you want to be a little defensive in a market like this, what do you rotate into right now?

DOLL: Higher quality. Just make sure the companies you own have decent balance sheets and have decent earnings and are not overly priced because valuation matters as interest rates and inflation creep higher.

FREEMAN: Bob -- the Fed was saying yesterday essentially that they think the economy can grow a little more over the next year, a little faster than they thought it could. But they still have a very pessimistic long-term view that we're kind of stuck in the new normal below 2 percent. Do you think they're wrong about that?

DOLL: I hope they're wrong about that. And look, this tax bill doesn't solve all our problems but for the first time the tax bill we got a couple of months ago gives us a chance to get productivity moving.

We've been stuck at 1 percent productivity. If we can get some intelligent capital expenditures, which this bill promotes, we can get productivity back toward 2 and then we have a higher growth rate than they're looking at, in my opinion.

MCDOWELL: What about headline risk and regulation risk? Deregulation has been a critical theme for this economy from the Trump administration over the last more than a year. But you see what's going on with Facebook, just irresponsible management with really some systemic problems at that company that investors are just noticing.

In a market like this which looks a little bit rich, are some stocks more at risk of these kind of negative headlines?

DOLL: That's absolutely true. We've been in an environment, thankfully, where we haven't had to worry about regulation because there have been no new ones and some of the old ones haven't been enforced, if you will.

But now we're in a position, Facebook is a good example, where we're going to have to take a look. And that will cast a bit of a gray cloud over those kinds of companies and perhaps the market as a whole.

MCDOWELL: Tech stocks?

DOLL: The big tech stocks that have grown like a weed and aren't domiciled anywhere and don't pay taxes anywhere, this is a place where the government is going to look.

BARTIROMO: How do you allocate capital then right now?

DOLL: So in my view you de-emphasize some of those stocks. You can still own tech but you own Mastercard and Visa and Cisco on the value side. You be a little more value-oriented in tech.

I think you still have to own some financials, Maria. I wouldn't give up on the consumer, selected places are still good as a result of the tax bill we talked about.

BARTIROMO: Are you worried about trade?

DOLL: You have to be worried about trade. When you put -- a tariff is a tax. Look, I'm --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DOLL: -- period, period, period.

Now, I know we've got to find a way to go after China because they don't play by the right rules. Everybody sees that, even the free traders. So we've got to find out a way to do that. So, you know, we started with a tariff on steel and aluminum for everybody.

Wait a minute, Mexico and Canada, you're our friends. We won't go there, maybe not Europe. Maybe this will get down to China.

MCDOWELL: Well, that's how I see it. I talk about Facebook -- that potential regulation. I see these tariffs and now companies have to ask for exemptions or even countries. That's additional regulation. You're putting up hurdles and who does that hurt? It hurts small business. This is something that President Trump knows.

BARTIROMO: By the way, even those countries that will be exempt, there will be quotas in place. So you will say ok, Canada, you're exempt from the tariffs but here's the amount of product we will take in terms of imports. There will be quotas instituted. They don't want over-capacity.

ROSCHELLE: And some of those countries are also talking about taxing those tech companies in Europe as well. So that's a headline that dovetails with what Dagen had to say. I agree with that. So that's a little -- another little gray cloud over there that we didn't have before.

BARTIROMO: Bob -- great to see you.

DOLL: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much. Bob Doll there.

Coming up, new scrutiny over self-driving cars, the very latest as police release a dash-cam video of that deadly crash involving one of Uber's autonomous vehicles.

Then, behind the mask, comedian Jim Carrey showing his true colors with a controversial painting believed to be White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders. Her father is with us, former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee will weigh in on an unflattering portrayal of his daughter.

Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back good Tuesday - - good Thursday morning to you (inaudible). Thanks for joining us everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, March 22nd. Your top stories right now at 7:30 a.m. on the east coast. Fears of a trade war sparking worries on Wall Street this morning. Ahead of the President's announcement on China tariffs and restrictions to investment here in the U.S. Futures indicating a decline of almost 200 points this morning, down 3/4 of a percent.

This after modest losses yesterday after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time this year. As you can see, yesterday's close was down fractional across the board. Markets across the globe mixed. FTSE 100 down 3/4 of a percent. The CAC (inaudible) and the DAX index goes down better than 1 percent. We did have some manufacturing data out. The Flash Purchasing Management Index out of Europe and that is one of the reasons that markets turned lower and the losses are accelerating this morning.

Also Japan Flash Manufacturing also under pressure. Asia over night as you can see also weaker although the NIKKEI average reported economic data came out was up about 1 percent. A new twist in the firing of Andrew McCabe. Reports say that the former FBI Deputy Director authorized an investigation into Attorney General Jeff Sessions for possible perjury. Plus the subpoena loans the House Judiciary Committee set to demand documents on the Hilary Clinton email investigation as you hear her first. We have the very latest there. New developments in the Uber self-driving crash investigation. Police releasing new video showing the moments just before the collision.

And Jim Carrey not quite Picasso. The actor turned painter under fire over his portrait of a woman who looks very similar to White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders. An unbelievable moment in Kosovo's parliament. The opposition party sets off tear gas to disrupt the vote. Ralph Macchio is returning. The original Karate Kid making his comeback in a new YouTube series. All that coming up this morning. But first, the aspired FBI official Andrew McCabe reported oversaw a Federal criminal probe of Attorney General Jeff Sessions according to ABC News.

McCabe reportedly authorized an investigation into whether the Attorney General lacked candor during his Congressional testimony last year about contact with Russian operatives. Sessions long time personal lawyer responded in a statement which reads, "The Special Counsel's Office has informed me that after interviewing the Attorney General and conducting an additional investigation. The Attorney General is not under investigation for false statements or perjury in his confirmation hearing testimony and related written submissions to Congress."

Joining us now is former presidential candidate from Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee. Governor Huckabee, I find this really rich. I mean, you know, here's a guy who basically in spying on Michael Flynn and then releasing that to the press committed perjury right there. And - - and that is a felony for - - for what he did and he also lacked candor himself and apparently he was investigating Sessions.

HUCKABEE: There's a statement Maria, something about karma being, gee I can't remember the rest of the phrase. But I would say that it applies here. It's just remarkable. I - - I think it's fine that he wanted to take a look to see was Jeff Sessions dishonest. But for all the people who are just crying big crocodile tears because Andrew McCabe got fired, my gosh get over it. Andrew McCabe deserved to be fired according the Office of Professional Responsibility. It wasn't Donald Trump who fired him. It was his own FBI organization who said he had to go.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: And why should he get a pension. If he violated the basic fundamental code of ethics that he supposedly clearly understood.

BARITROMO: Yes. I mean - - we - - we want to move on to the spending and your tweet earlier. But - - but I find it really incredible that there are 1.2 million documents that the House Oversight and House Judiciary Committees have requested from the FBI and they've only sent 3,000 documents, 3,000 documents. That's why they are subpoenaing those documents this week. But, how does that happen? How do you blow off and stonewall the committees that have jurisdiction over you for so long?

HUCKABEE: Well that's part of the problem when there's so much power that has been accumulated at the top of the FBI. And I think everybody tries to make the point, this isn't about the rank and file. This isn't about the organization but this is about the leadership and the corruption that has so permeated that organization that they think they have the right to slow walk getting documents over to the Oversight committee.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: That they are constitutionally required to be accountable for.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HUCKABEE: It's absurd and I'm glad Bob Goodlatte is saying, here's a subpoena.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HUCKABEE: Cough up - - cough up the stuff.

BARTIROMO: But, by the way, Jason Chavitz tried that too and they - - they - - he didn't get anywhere either. He - - he - - remember when he interrupted a meeting and said you are served. But anyway, let me switch gears because Arkansas Congressman and House Budget Committee Chairman Steve Womack responded to your tweet. Your tweet called out Republicans about the Federal spending bill and you - - you called it a disgusting bill. Just say no to Pelosi. Here's what he said earlier right here on the program.

(VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: They needed to make concessions to pay for the military governor.

HUCKABEE: Well look, Steve is a good friend and I love him. He's a great Congressman but I'm going to just say this. Not one Republican in that body got elected to fund Planned Parenthood, not fund the Border Wall, give up for sanctuary cities, trash the 2nd Amendment. They were elected to go and do a job that stopped that kind of funding but it did fund the military. So lay it on the table and tell the Democrats. We're going to fund the military but we're not going to fund some of your pet projects and you can either be the ones that keep us from having a strong military or you can join us. And if you think that we're wrong than you go get elected to the majorities.

These guys have got to start learning to play some hardball. They have surrendered to Schumer and Pelosi and to a minority, and there is just no excuse for just giving up this quickly. And if the government has to shutdown in order to push that point, then maybe that's what has to happen and lay it around the necks of Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi and Democrats who think that killing unborn children is more important than being able to preserve the boarders and the security of the United States of America. That's what's at stake and it's time for them to stand up and do what they sent them there to do and if they can't, get some more people and let them have a shot at it.

ROSCHELLE: Governor, Mitch Roschelle. One of the things when I talk to business leaders I hear a lot of this fear about the mid-term elections and how that could shift policy for the balance of this Administration's first term. How could this budget issue play out in the mid-terms and be used as sort of fodder for beating up some Republican candidates?

HUCKABEE: I - - I'll be very blunt. If the Republicans surrender on this bill and spend that kind of money on stuff that Republicans find immoral and just absolutely unacceptable, then Republicans will lose. They will deserve to lose. We're going to have a lousy government under Democrats when Pelosi goes back in as Speaker. But it won't be the fault of the President and it won't be the fault of rank and file Republicans. It will be the fault of this Congress for not having the courage to stand up to these guys and say, we got elected. Why don't they just say what Obama did. Elections have consequences and roll that tape over and over and over again. Because I'll guarantee you the Democrats certainly didn't compromise with Republicans when they had the whole show.

FREEMAN: Governor, you make some good points on policies that Washington shouldn't be funding. But isn't the big problem here also the overall level of spending?

HUCKABEE: Of course it is. Yes, James it is. And I think that's another issue that Republicans went to Congress to cut this runaway spending. The - - the - - scenarios where Republicans are willing to spend. We're willing to spend to build a border wall, willing to fund the military but we're not willing to just say let's have a grab bag and everybody gets to throw in what they want. $1.3 trillion is - - is way beyond what is should be and the Republicans act like they don't have a choice.

And they're wringing their hands and they're sweating blood. Well it's time for them to stand up and say, nope. Again, we got elected - - we got elected to do some specific things, here are the specific things and if you don't want to vote for it we're going to tell the whole country that you thought that killing unborn babies and running up a huge deficit was more important to you than making sure that we had security and border protection.

BARTIROMO: Governor, let me switch gears, ask you about this crazy photo. Look, I know that as a father you're incredibly proud of Sarah, your daughter. She has to deal with constant everyday pushback from skeptics. Jim Carrey painted this. He - - the black lash is incredible after posting this photo. It's believed to be Sarah - - Sarah Huckabee Sanders, your daughter. Last week he tweeted out this picture with a caption that reads, this is the portrait of a so-called Christian who's only purpose in life is to lie for the wicked monstrous. So, the actor has drawn pictures criticizing President Trump as well. What do you say governor?

HUCKABEE: Well first of all I think as far as his political leanings, we're going to just mark him down as undecided. He just hasn't been that clear where he stands.

(LAUGHTER)

HUCKABEE: But if he wants to paint some ridiculous looking cartoons, that's what political cartoonists do. That's one thing. I - - I'm not as so much offended by that. I think it's unfair and unflattering but my daughter's a beautiful person inside and out. Here's what I find and take offense to. It is the fact that he calls her a so-called Christian and accusing her of lies without listing what those lies are. And - - and to question someone's faith, you don't hear him talk about a so-called Muslim or a so-called Jew or a so-called Buddhist. I think it's just something that the left takes in vogue as to be able to attack people of the Christian faith and somehow believe that they become judge and jury as if they are the Father, Son and Holy Ghost when it comes to determining the authenticity of a person's faith. That's what I find most offensive.

BARTIROMO: So rude, offensive. You're right.

HUCKABEE: He doesn't know her faith. That's offensive.

MCDOWELL: And - - now I'll just add one thing. These people on the left, these spew. They spew hate at me all day long. If they spent a little more time trying to get HRC elected, they wouldn't be so doggone angry. Again, it's asymmetric rage. Angry at something, angry at something in a way that doesn't even make any sense.

BARTIROMO: But that's all - - that's all they do is shame people and name call. It's - - it's - - it's not even a fair fight. It's - - it's nothing of substance. It's just name calling, painting a picture of someone.

MCDOWELL: To be fair though, people - - ardent Trump supporters who are 100 percent on board with everything the President does like tariffs. I've gotten as much hate from Trump supporters when I talk about tariffs being a tax. So I think everybody needs to check their soul.

FREEMAN: The governor's daughter is earning all the right enemies here.

(CROSSTALK)

HUCKABEE: Well said. Sometimes you're known by your friends. Sometimes you're known by your enemies And I think, you know, if - - if those are her enemies than she's in very good shape.

BARTIROMO: Yes, absolutely. Governor, good to see you sir. Thanks so much.

HUCKABEE: Thanks a bunch. Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Mike Huckabee there. Coming up a vote takes a violent turn in Kosovo. Look at this, the chaos after a tear gas grenade is set off in the middle of the tense debate.

Welcome back. Police releasing a disturbing video from last Sunday's accident when an Uber self driving car struck and killed a pedestrian in Tempe - - in Tempe, Arizona. Lauren Simonetti with the details.

SIMONETTI: Hello Maria. This is video we want to warn you that is pretty tough to watch. It shows the safety driver, the minder not looking at the road in the final moments before he hit - - hit a 49 year old Elaine Herzberg. This is believed to be the first fatal crash that involves the self-driving vehicle and a pedestrian. Uber has suspended testing of it's self-driving vehicles. Toyota has also halted it's tests on - - on public roads. But it begs the question, if you're minding the vehicle, do you have to pay attention at all times even though it's autonomous?

All right, take a look at this one. Some opposition lawmakers in Kosovo firing tear gas in the parliament chamber. They wanted to block a vote on a border deal with Montenegro. Despite this attack, the - - the measure was approved in an 80 to 11 vote. The border deal is set as a pre- condition by the European Union for Kosovo citizens to travel within it's visa free zone. So that's what some opposition leaders did there. And let's have - - let's lighten if up. Thirty-four years since Daniel LaRusso learned to wax on, wax off and his rivalry with Johnny Lawrence lives on in the YouTube Red series Cobra Kai.

(VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: This is my childhood. YouTube releasing a trailer for the new series in which Ralph Macchio and William Zabka reprise their roles. It's a show that premieres on May 2nd. (inaudible) takes place in a car dealership, in the future. I love it. Thank you.

(ROSCHELLE): Yes baby. Come on.

BARTIROMO: I knew you were going to say that.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Coming up, bidding like it is 1999. Your chance to buy a piece of Prince and other music legends. A first hand look at the iconic items hitting the auction block next.

From Michael Jackson to Elvis Presley and Prince, iconic celebrity items are coming to the auction block this weekend at GWS Auctions, Legends of Hollywood and Music Auction. We have some of the big items right here on set. And here joining me to tell us all about it is - - is Brigitte Kruse. She is owner and chief auctioneer of GWS Auction in Los Angeles. Brigitte, good to see you.

KRUSE: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us. I love that you - - that you brought all this stuff. We're going to go through it. How did you get into this auction business?

KRUSE: You know what? It was a family business. I'm actually 5th generation so I don't think I had much choice to get into this business. It's - - it's a labor of love.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, you must love it. Because you've got all of these beautiful things and you - - what - - what moves the price in terms of some of these items?

KRUSE: That is a great question. It's mostly trends, what's popular, what's not. You know, you just kind of have to follow it. It changes from time to time. And then there's things, there's certain asset categories that just are timeless and always are popular.

BARTIROMO: Yes they sure are. So let's start with the Prince. The purple overcoat used by the late Prince during the filming of "Purple Rain". Tell us about this item.

KRUSE: This piece actually came from the daughter-in-law of one of the set designers from "Purple Rain". And with it being such an iconic film for that time, you know, I believe it grossed over $80 million in 1984 which was unheard of.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

KRUSE: So, you know, with the lace detail and little pearl inserts, it's just a lovely piece.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KRUSE: We're really excited about it.

BARTIROMO: What do you think this will go for?

KRUSE: You know what, we're predicting somewhere conservatively in the $3,500 to $5,000 range.

BARTIROMO: I see. OK. And - - and when people buy these items, they do it to collect and put them somewhere where they will just save them and cherish them and make sure that the value stays. You're not going to like wear it.

KRUSE: Definitely. And that's something that we do that's just a little bit different. We actually make sure that these pieces are perfect by the time they get to the bidder's hands. So if we have a successful bidder, we want to make sure that they receive the most pristine asset possible.

BARTIROMO: Let's look at this one. One of the rare left-handed version of Michael Jackson's trademark glove. Tell me about that one.

KRUSE: So, this is what they consider the second generation Michael Jackson glove. There is the Bill Witten (ph) glove who is, you know, he is infamous for helping Michael Jackson create the first generation. And this is the Michael Bush-Dennis Tompkins era, which is kind of the second generation glove. So this was more during the time, right when he married Lisa Marie.

BARTIROMO: Wow. And then the other one that we wanted to see, Michael Jackson item is the fedora owned by the King of Pop. Tell me about that one.

KRUSE: Oh yes. He made an empire out of fedoras. So - -

BARTIROMO: They're both his?

KRUSE: Yes. They're both his.

BARTIROMO: OK. Go ahead.

KRUSE: And the neat story with these is there was a gentleman who made a donation by way of an art piece to one of Michael Jackson's charitable foundations. And in - - in time he gave them three fedoras. So these are two of those three fedoras and they actually are - - they have great providence. They come with a letter of authenticity from MJJ Productions which is as solid as it gets.

BARTIROMO: So cool. And this bid starts at $500.

KRUSE: Correct.

BARTIROMO: All right. So let's go through this one, speaking of kings. You have an Army book owned and autographed by Elvis Presley himself.

KRUSE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

KRUSE: This is one of my favorite items because at the time, in 1958 when he went to Germany, a lot of people think that that was kind of a turning point for his career. Because they say that he never quite came back the same. But what makes this piece so special is this was when he met Priscilla over in Germany when he was stationed there. And this Army book actually belonged to someone who served with him and he got so excited when he saw him, will you please sign it.

BARTIROMO: How fantastic.

KRUSE: And it's - - it's never been offered at auction before.

BARTIROMO: Where do you think that starts at?

KRUSE: You know what, the bid is currently at $3,300 and I'm going to tell you. I am surprised by that. So, you know, I think we might end up in the $5,000 range by the time we have auction (inaudible).

BARTIROMO: That's an interesting item. That's - - that's history right there.

KRUSE: It is.

BARTIROMO: The blue fir smock worn by Lady Gaga on American Horror Story. This is just fabulous.

KRUSE: It is actually what we call a bi-lateral celebrity piece. Because it was also worn by Halle Barry in "Why Do Fools Fall In Love", the Frankie Limon story.

BARTIROMO: OK.

KRUSE: So, this has got a really cool back story. And this came from one of our wardrobe houses in Hollywood.

BARTIROMO: So where - - where - - where - - why do you have it? I mean, after - - after those two celebrities wore it?

KRUSE: A lot of these places have to do asset management. You know, they have to take care of these assets, get them in, get them out after they've been used so many times. So we were just fortunate enough to be the one in line.

BARTIROMO: Real quick. The big pair of sunglasses owned by the late Steve McQueen.

KRUSE: Yes. Oh my gosh, the Versoles (ph). I mean, he was known for the folding sunglasses. So we're excited about those and the bid is already over $5,000. So - -

BARTIROMO: Very cool. Brigitte, thank you. The auction begins - -

KRUSE: On Saturday, 10 a.m. Pacific.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be checking it out. Thanks so much.

KRUSE: Thank you Maria.

BARTIROMO: Brigitte Kruse. We'll be right back. Stay with us.

END
