urn:contentItem:5RGR-M6S1-JBHT-D4Y4-00000-00Shut Down: The Government Just Hours Away From A Partial Shutdown. Outrage On Capitol Hill Over Surveillance; Dow Closes At Second Highest2018-01-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisShut Down: The Government Just Hours Away From A Partial Shutdown. Outrage On Capitol Hill Over Surveillance; Dow Closes At Second HighestLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, January 19th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Shutdown showdown -- the House doing its part to avoid a government shutdown, passing a short-term spending bill last night that will keep the government funded through February 16th. However, now it is on to the Senate where passage remains anything but certain. One of the major hurdles: immigration reform, specifically a DACA deal.

The Department of Justice has asked the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court ruling that blocks the President's decision to phase out the program. This comes as a new report says as nearly four million Dreamers are in the U.S. -- a far greater number than originally known. The latest on immigration reform, coming up.

Markets this morning: stocks pulled back slightly yesterday but all three major indices closed at their second highest level in history. Yesterday the Dow down 97 points and part of the reason -- bonds, the yields went up. The 10-year yield rose to the highest level in nearly four years topping 2.6 percent yesterday. It remains at that level right now.

Futures this morning nonetheless bouncing back -- take a look. We've got the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 92 points reversing all of yesterday's selloff. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq also positively.

In Europe this morning, similar story. Money is moving into equities; FT 100 up a quarter of a percent, CAC 40 up almost half a percent, the DAX in Germany up almost 1 percent.

Check the Asian markets -- stocks ended the week higher, as you see there. Best performers were in Asia -- Shanghai and Hang Seng.

An alarming report to report -- a confidential intelligence memo that alleges abuses made by government surveillance is being called "troubling" by lawmakers. Several Republicans want that memo to be made public.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SCOTT PERRY (R), PENNSYLVANIA: You knew as soon as you read them and you think about -- is this happening in America or is it the KGB? That is how alarming it is.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R), OHIO: What I read today in that classified briefing room is as bad as I thought it was and every single American citizen should have the ability to see that information, to know exactly what our FBI was up to.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Yes. So they want to release the memo -- how it ties to Robert Mueller's Russia probe, coming up.

Plus Starbucks brewing up a place on Fortune's list of the world's most admired companies. It is not number one -- find out who took that top spot.

Plus the relationship with the U.S. not the only icy thing in Vladimir Putin's life. Check this out. Why the Russian leader takes a dip in freezing water.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: former State Department spokesperson, national security adviser to President Obama's presidential campaign and Fox News contributor Marie Harf is here; the King's College business and economics professor Brian Brenberg; and Fox Business Network's Connell McShane.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN HOST: We can't unsee that, can we?

BARTIROMO: It's the morning --

(CROSSTALK)

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: No. No.

BARTIROMO: And I will never get that two minutes back.

MCSHANE: Why did you do that then?

BRIAN BRENBERG, THE KING'S COLLEGE: We already this serious conversation and then that picture shows up. You can't remember what you're --

BARTIROMO: He loves taking off his shirt.

MCSHANE: I was about to make a comment -- you know, it's interesting the markets (INAUDIBLE). No matter what they kind of -- and then Putin with no shirt.

(CROSSTALK)

HARF: Happy Friday.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God. Happy Friday.

MCSHANE: It is kind of interesting that the markets -- I mean if they're worried about a government shutdown, right, it's kind of a funny way for stocks showing it. They keep on bouncing back.

BRENBERG: Maybe a little bit of dollar weakness leading up to this but -- I don't know.

BARTIROMO: You would think that the market is looking for any excuse to sort of come in just a little after almost, you know, $7.5 trillion in value in the last year and a half. And yes, even a government shutdown.

BRENBERG: Yes.

MCSHANE: They must be expecting it to be short. But I just don't know if they're going to pull this together in time. I think Republicans need something like 12 votes in the Senate in order to get something passed. Can they do that?

BRENBERG: No.

HARF: Not by tonight. I don't think by tonight.

MCSHANE: Twelve -- I don't think so.

BARTIROMO: Big victory in the House because the Freedom Caucus was sort of pushing, pushing, and actually they were able to rally up the votes and pass it in the House.

But now, once again --

MCSHANE: Short term maybe. It's the only thing, right. Maybe they get to four or five -- four-day -- they were talking about that last night. Maybe something real short-term but there's no way, to your point, to get to 60 on this bill. No way.

HARF: Certainly not. And not by tonight. I think they want to make a point here. And with a one vote majority in the Senate on the Republican side -- some folks still not in D.C. I think we shut down for a few days.

BRENBERG: But I think Democrats are really gambling here that Republicans get blamed for this. And I just don't know. I mean I know that's the trend in the past.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BRENBERG: But the way this is shaping up now, especially with the good news on taxes, the Democrats --

HARF: They're in charge though, man.

BRENBERG: I don't know. I don't know -- Maria. You've got confidence there. But I think this could go the other way.

HARF: We'll see.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll watch that and obviously talking about that all morning this morning.

Joining the conversation, the counselor to the President -- President Trump, Kellyanne Conway will join me, coming up. She will weigh in on the shocking memo circulating in Congress that allegedly details FISA abuses and the shutdown showdown in the Senate. She'll join us shortly. You don't want to miss that.

First though this -- this top story. And that is the looming government shutdown. Congress is deadlocked over the passage of a four-week stop gap spending, keeping Capitol Hill open past today's deadline. Tensions are flaring across the aisle.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: Senator Schumer -- do not shutdown the federal government. It is risky. It is reckless. And it is wrong.

I ask the American people to understand this. The only people standing in the way of keeping the government open are Senate Democrats.

SENATOR CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: I'm not trying to play for political points, even false ones. I am trying to get us to come together on a bipartisan nature to get something done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us this morning is New York Republican Congressman and Trump transition team executive committee member Chris Collins. Congressman -- it's good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

REP. CHRIS COLLINS (R), NEW YORK: Yes. Good to be with you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think? What are the chances of a government shutdown?

COLLINS: Well, you know, we got our job done in the House yet again. And this would be a Chuck Schumer shutdown. The Schumer shutdown does look like a possibility. I've just got to hope as he looks into his political playbook, he realizes he's going to wear this one.

And we don't know but again, the House did our job. And it would be a shame for America to have Senator Schumer not deliver the Democrat vote. He is all political all the time. There's no two ways about it.

I remind people when we saw the tears last time they were real. He wanted to be majority leader of the Senate and he still does.

And so, you know, he is trying to weigh who wears this. He's not looking out for what is best for America. He's looking out what is best for senator Schumer and how does this play into his desire to be the majority leader of the Senate. It is that simple.

BARTIROMO: But do the voters know that? I mean are the voters going to hold him accountable come November, you think? I mean -- or do you think the Republicans get blamed should the government shutdown?

COLLINS: Well, because we did, Maria, passed this in the House, the Republicans passed it in the House. The Democrats one and all voted against the six-year extension of the Child Health Insurance Program -- something that's always been bipartisan.

And if Senator Schumer says he is looking out for the DACA or the dreamers I'd like to remind him and remind America back in 2009 and '10 when Harry Reid, Nancy Pelosi, Barack Obama controlled the government in its entirety with 60 senators, they did nothing for these DACA kids other than as Obama said, "I've got a phone and a pen". He signed an executive order that effectively expired when he left office.

So it begs the question Senator Schumer, why didn't the Democrats fix our immigration issues back in 2009 and '10 when they could have. And oh, by the way, why didn't you raise minimum wage back in 2009 and '10 when you could have?

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's a good point.

MCSHANE: I wonder if your concerned though about the perception of it because the Democratic argument here will be that -- hey we've had -- whatever it is 17, 18 shutdowns going back to the 70s but we've never had one quite like this where one party had the House, the Senate and the White House.

They're going to basically say, as I think Marie said a few minutes, hey listen, you guys are in charge. And that argument might resonate. Are you concerned with that politically?

COLLINS: Well, here is what I hope politically if this does happen that Leader McConnell realizes it's time to get rid of the filibuster once and for all. Because again, we've done it now and the Supreme Court judges because of senator Schumer. I'll say thank you Senator Schumer for being such an obstructionist that we had no choice but get rid of the filibuster through Supreme Court judges.

Well, maybe here is another example why that rule of the Senate, it's not in the constitution. It's nothing more than an archaic rule that should be eliminated. Now then you could blame us. But when you need 60 votes in the Senate and it's Senator Schumer that's got to deliver.

This is a Schumer shutdown were it to occur --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

COLLINS: -- and I think we would absolutely remind the American public of that.

BARTIROMO: -- which is why the President is tweeting on this right now actually. He just tweeted on the shutdown saying this, "Government funding bill passed last night in the House of Representatives. Now Democrats are needed if it is to pass in the Senate. But they want illegal immigration and a weak border. Shutdown coming? We need more Republican victories in 2018."

So Congressman Collins -- How are you going to get more Republican victories in 2018 when you are sitting on the precipice of a government shutdown and the perception will be that Republicans are at fault?

COLLINS: Well, that is perception and we've got to make sure the reality - - the truth comes out and we are sitting now on the most historic tax reform in 31 years. And now worker after worker is going to see more money in their paycheck.

And that's the playbook we have is the fundamental tax reform, more money in workers' pockets, higher 401(k), balances, the economy rocking and rolling, and we're company after company increasing their starting wages. And we will make sure that anyone and everyone knows this is, if it happens, Schumer shutdown.

BRENBERG: But Congressman, you know, to that point, even if this looks like -- even if people think it is the Schumer shutdown, the problem is this news dominates headlines instead of the news we've seen over past few days with Apple and other companies.

To me the Republicans are going to lose with the shutdown either way because the good news story, and it's a great news story on tax cuts, just is not going to get through.

Frankly I think Democrats like that. I think that's why they are gunning for a shutdown here.

COLLINS: Oh, there's no doubt that Senator Schumer is looking -- but it's risky for him -- at the political outcomes here. And again, now that we passed it in the House, it is the Democrats we need in the Senate.

So we will have to see how this plays out. Both parties lose, America loses and that is what I'd be saying to Senator Schumer. Let's do what's right for America.

We should also remind all Americans, all essential services in the government will continue, our military and everyone else. But the headlines were falling for (ph) this morning, models from 14 different automakers have been recalled to replace defective Takata airbags.

The new list released by US safety regulators include vehicles made by Ford, BMW, Fiat Chrysler, Nissan, and Volkswagen.

Takata announcing it was recalling an additional 3.3 million airbags in December as part of the large - as part of the largest recall in the US history; at least 21 people worldwide, those deaths have been linked to faulty Takata inflators.

Well reports this morning out of the - Snapchat's parent company, has laid off about two dozen workers.

Cheddar first broke the news, Snapchat has also asked a handful of employees in New York and London to relocate to Los Angeles where the company is based.

The move comes amid delays in SNAP's efforts to overhaul its app and build up its content; of course, they haven't even been public a year Maria as shares of SNAP slightly higher in the premarket, up almost one percent but some rough (ph) news (INAUDIBLE) there.

BARTIROMO: All right.

Cheryl thank you.

Coming up the world's most admired companies of 2018, Apple wins the first spot, this last year but will the technology titan hold onto the top spot this year?

We will tell you, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Now, this FOX BUSINESS exclusive, Fortune Magazine revealing the world's most admired companies this year, the publication polled nearly 4,000 executives, analysts, experts, to rank the best businesses of 2018.

For the top-class companies overall Starbucks claimed fifth place; Berkshire Hathaway coming in fourth; third-place Alphabet, parent of Google; Amazon having the second place; and coming in first, Apple.

Once again.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE) drum-roll (INAUDIBLE).

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE) --

BARTIROMO: Joining us -- UNIDENTIFIED MALE: -- (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: -- joining us now --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: -- (INAUDIBLE), come on guys.

Joining us now the Fortune Magazine Deputy Editor, Brian O'Keefe.

Brian, good to see you.

BRIAN O'KEEFE, DEPUTY EDITOR FORTUNE MAGAZINE: Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining --

O'KEEFE: -- you're inspired --

BARTIROMO: -- us.

O'KEEFE: -- by the (INAUDIBLE) a minute ago, right?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

Yes, right.

O'KEEFE: (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: Tell us what goes into this? What do you look at to come up with the most admired?

O'KEEFE: Well we go out, we partner with Korn Ferry and they go out to as you said, polled 4,000 executives across all these industries, 52 industries. Well we get companies to - well the executives from these companies and industry experts to rank the companies in the -- each industry.

And then we also asked them to vote on the most admired companies across all industries and that's how we get our top 50.

PROFESSOR BRIAN BRENBERG, EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT & CHAIR OF BUSINESS AND FINANCE AT KING'S COLLEGE & FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: So anything - but I've got (ph) - I'm a little self-conscious that all our parent companies are a little too far down the (INAUDIBLE).

I guess you can make an argument for Disney but I'm sure it's their entertainment assets and their theme parks right, that get them in the - in the top, not their --

O'KEEFE: Yes.

BRENBERG: -- media (ph) assets.

O'KEEFE: I mean the way they run their theme parks --

BRENBERG: Yes.

O'KEEFE: -- I don't know when was the last time you were at Disney World though (ph) but it's incredible you know, the way they operate.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX NEWS ANCHOR, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Yes.

BRENBERG: So, these are not just the companies that you want to work for, they are the companies --

MARIE HARF, FORMER SPOKESPERSON U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT & FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes.

BRENBERG: -- you like their products, you like their marketing, you like their story, it's bigger than just who do you want to work - or maybe it doesn't have anything to do with who you want to --

O'KEEFE: And I --

BRENBERG: -- work with?

O'KEEFE: -- think it's rival executives, people that say, 'hey, I would like my company to be as successful as these companies are,' you know, --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

O'KEEFE: -- everyone wants to be as successful as Apple.

Apple's number one for the 11th straight year, no --

BARTIROMO: Oh.

O'KEEFE: -- coincidence that their stocks up you know, 13 times over that period so --

BARTIROMO: Thirteen times and yesterday we spoke with Roger McNamee from Elevation Partners, a really astute investor in Technology, here's what he said about Apple; listen to this?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER OF SILVER LAKE PARTNERS, MANAGING DIRECTOR & CO- FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS: I actually think Apple is a company everybody should pay attention to.

I work - admire Apple more than any company that's out there today and I think that they are the one check in our economy on Google, on Facebook. They have done some great things to protect consumers and importantly, I think they are undervalued even though it's the largest cap in the - the largest market cap of any stock in the world.

I think what they're doing is absolutely brilliant.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Isn't that interesting?

Even undervalued as - it's - and 13 times over?

O'KEEFE: Yes.

Yes, 13 times - 13-fold increase in 11 years, 900 billion-dollar marketing cap, I mean that's incredible,

They're - they're PE has tended to be lower than a lot of those other big tech companies over the last several years so you know, I - is everybody ready to go all in on Apple right now?

I don't know.

MCSHANE: So, Apple is in the news yesterday but GE is in the news yesterday --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BRENBERG: -- as well and --

BARTIROMO: Good point.

MCSHANE: -- you know, they were at the top of the - I mean (INAUDIBLE) look back and find that they were top of this list, how often is somebody at the top of the list, kind of a sign that, everybody loves them but the world is changing, don't expect them to stay there.

O'KEEFE: Well GE, it's interesting you mention that, I mean they were a perennial on the list, there were number seven last year, they dropped to number 30 this year and that was even before the latest stuff.

I mean, will - we'll see if they are on the list next year --

MCSHANE: Yes.

O'KEEFE: -- they're not going in the right direction, obviously their stock is down 45 percent, last year, it's kind of a sad --

BARTIROMO: They cut --

O'KEEFE: 's story.

BARTIROMO: -- the dividend, it is a sad --

O'KEEFE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- story. It's a 125-year-old company --

BRENBERG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but you made a really good point Marie in the commercial break saying, 'you can't believe Southwest Airlines is still there --

HARF: I love it (ph).

BARTIROMO: -- and do other airlines vote for Southwest?

HARF: Right, I mean it's - it's shocking that an airline of that statue (ph) is that high above Facebook which Americans use constantly almost (ph) --

BRENBERG: Yes.

HARF: -- everyday.

O'KEEFE: Well as you were saying you know, they haven't made the headlines for the wrong reasons and you --

BARTIROMO: Sure.

O'KEEFE: -- know I think that they've operated so well through different oil price environments and the different operating environments and downturns you know, I think people just really, really, admire what they do.

BARTIROMO: Great list (ph).

Thank you, Brian.

We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Good Friday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, January 19th; your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RFK-SNN1-DXH2-612N-00000-00Shut Down: The Government Just Hours Away From A Partial Shutdown. Outrage On Capitol Hill Over Surveillance; Dow Closes At Second Highest Level Ever; The 10-Year Yield Rising To The Highest Level In Nearly 4 Years; Fortune Magazine Picks Apple As The Most Admired Company; GOP Lawmakers Demand The Release Of FISA Abuses Memo; Blood Test That Can Develop Up To Eight Different Cancers2018-01-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMatt Gaetz; Kellyanne Conway; Jim Jordan; Brian O'KeefeNEWSFinancial011902cb.231Shut Down: The Government Just Hours Away From A Partial Shutdown. Outrage On Capitol Hill Over Surveillance; Dow Closes At Second Highest Level Ever; The 10-Year Yield Rising To The Highest Level In Nearly 4 Years; Fortune Magazine Picks Apple As The Most Admired Company; GOP Lawmakers Demand The Release Of FISA Abuses Memo; Blood Test That Can Develop Up To Eight Different CancersMaria Bartiromo; Marie Harf; Brian Brenberg; Connell McShane; Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, January 19th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Shutdown showdown -- the House doing its part to avoid a government shutdown, passing a short-term spending bill last night that will keep the government funded through February 16th. However, now it is on to the Senate where passage remains anything but certain. One of the major hurdles: immigration reform, specifically a DACA deal.

The Department of Justice has asked the Supreme Court to overturn a lower court ruling that blocks the President's decision to phase out the program. This comes as a new report says as nearly four million Dreamers are in the U.S. -- a far greater number than originally known. The latest on immigration reform, coming up.

Markets this morning: stocks pulled back slightly yesterday but all three major indices closed at their second highest level in history. Yesterday the Dow down 97 points and part of the reason -- bonds, the yields went up. The 10-year yield rose to the highest level in nearly four years topping 2.6 percent yesterday. It remains at that level right now.

Futures this morning nonetheless bouncing back -- take a look. We've got the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 92 points reversing all of yesterday's selloff. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq also positively.

In Europe this morning, similar story. Money is moving into equities; FT 100 up a quarter of a percent, CAC 40 up almost half a percent, the DAX in Germany up almost 1 percent.

Check the Asian markets -- stocks ended the week higher, as you see there. Best performers were in Asia -- Shanghai and Hang Seng.

An alarming report to report -- a confidential intelligence memo that alleges abuses made by government surveillance is being called "troubling" by lawmakers. Several Republicans want that memo to be made public.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SCOTT PERRY (R), PENNSYLVANIA: You knew as soon as you read them and you think about -- is this happening in America or is it the KGB? That is how alarming it is.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R), OHIO: What I read today in that classified briefing room is as bad as I thought it was and every single American citizen should have the ability to see that information, to know exactly what our FBI was up to.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Yes. So they want to release the memo -- how it ties to Robert Mueller's Russia probe, coming up.

Plus Starbucks brewing up a place on Fortune's list of the world's most admired companies. It is not number one -- find out who took that top spot.

Plus the relationship with the U.S. not the only icy thing in Vladimir Putin's life. Check this out. Why the Russian leader takes a dip in freezing water.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: former State Department spokesperson, national security adviser to President Obama's presidential campaign and Fox News contributor Marie Harf is here; the King's College business and economics professor Brian Brenberg; and Fox Business Network's Connell McShane.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN HOST: We can't unsee that, can we?

BARTIROMO: It's the morning --

(CROSSTALK)

MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: No. No.

BARTIROMO: And I will never get that two minutes back.

MCSHANE: Why did you do that then?

BRIAN BRENBERG, THE KING'S COLLEGE: We already this serious conversation and then that picture shows up. You can't remember what you're --

BARTIROMO: He loves taking off his shirt.

MCSHANE: I was about to make a comment -- you know, it's interesting the markets (INAUDIBLE). No matter what they kind of -- and then Putin with no shirt.

(CROSSTALK)

HARF: Happy Friday.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God. Happy Friday.

MCSHANE: It is kind of interesting that the markets -- I mean if they're worried about a government shutdown, right, it's kind of a funny way for stocks showing it. They keep on bouncing back.

BRENBERG: Maybe a little bit of dollar weakness leading up to this but -- I don't know.

BARTIROMO: You would think that the market is looking for any excuse to sort of come in just a little after almost, you know, $7.5 trillion in value in the last year and a half. And yes, even a government shutdown.

BRENBERG: Yes.

MCSHANE: They must be expecting it to be short. But I just don't know if they're going to pull this together in time. I think Republicans need something like 12 votes in the Senate in order to get something passed. Can they do that?

BRENBERG: No.

HARF: Not by tonight. I don't think by tonight.

MCSHANE: Twelve -- I don't think so.

BARTIROMO: Big victory in the House because the Freedom Caucus was sort of pushing, pushing, and actually they were able to rally up the votes and pass it in the House.

But now, once again --

MCSHANE: Short term maybe. It's the only thing, right. Maybe they get to four or five -- four-day -- they were talking about that last night. Maybe something real short-term but there's no way, to your point, to get to 60 on this bill. No way.

HARF: Certainly not. And not by tonight. I think they want to make a point here. And with a one vote majority in the Senate on the Republican side -- some folks still not in D.C. I think we shut down for a few days.

BRENBERG: But I think Democrats are really gambling here that Republicans get blamed for this. And I just don't know. I mean I know that's the trend in the past.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BRENBERG: But the way this is shaping up now, especially with the good news on taxes, the Democrats --

HARF: They're in charge though, man.

BRENBERG: I don't know. I don't know -- Maria. You've got confidence there. But I think this could go the other way.

HARF: We'll see.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll watch that and obviously talking about that all morning this morning.

Joining the conversation, the counselor to the President -- President Trump, Kellyanne Conway will join me, coming up. She will weigh in on the shocking memo circulating in Congress that allegedly details FISA abuses and the shutdown showdown in the Senate. She'll join us shortly. You don't want to miss that.

First though this -- this top story. And that is the looming government shutdown. Congress is deadlocked over the passage of a four-week stop gap spending, keeping Capitol Hill open past today's deadline. Tensions are flaring across the aisle.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. PAUL RYAN (R-WI), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: Senator Schumer -- do not shutdown the federal government. It is risky. It is reckless. And it is wrong.

I ask the American people to understand this. The only people standing in the way of keeping the government open are Senate Democrats.

SENATOR CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: I'm not trying to play for political points, even false ones. I am trying to get us to come together on a bipartisan nature to get something done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us this morning is New York Republican Congressman and Trump transition team executive committee member Chris Collins. Congressman -- it's good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

REP. CHRIS COLLINS (R), NEW YORK: Yes. Good to be with you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: What do you think? What are the chances of a government shutdown?

COLLINS: Well, you know, we got our job done in the House yet again. And this would be a Chuck Schumer shutdown. The Schumer shutdown does look like a possibility. I've just got to hope as he looks into his political playbook, he realizes he's going to wear this one.

And we don't know but again, the House did our job. And it would be a shame for America to have Senator Schumer not deliver the Democrat vote. He is all political all the time. There's no two ways about it.

I remind people when we saw the tears last time they were real. He wanted to be majority leader of the Senate and he still does.

And so, you know, he is trying to weigh who wears this. He's not looking out for what is best for America. He's looking out what is best for senator Schumer and how does this play into his desire to be the majority leader of the Senate. It is that simple.

BARTIROMO: But do the voters know that? I mean are the voters going to hold him accountable come November, you think? I mean -- or do you think the Republicans get blamed should the government shutdown?

COLLINS: Well, because we did, Maria, passed this in the House, the Republicans passed it in the House. The Democrats one and all voted against the six-year extension of the Child Health Insurance Program -- something that's always been bipartisan.

And if Senator Schumer says he is looking out for the DACA or the dreamers I'd like to remind him and remind America back in 2009 and '10 when Harry Reid, Nancy Pelosi, Barack Obama controlled the government in its entirety with 60 senators, they did nothing for these DACA kids other than as Obama said, "I've got a phone and a pen". He signed an executive order that effectively expired when he left office.

So it begs the question Senator Schumer, why didn't the Democrats fix our immigration issues back in 2009 and '10 when they could have. And oh, by the way, why didn't you raise minimum wage back in 2009 and '10 when you could have?

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's a good point.

MCSHANE: I wonder if your concerned though about the perception of it because the Democratic argument here will be that -- hey we've had -- whatever it is 17, 18 shutdowns going back to the 70s but we've never had one quite like this where one party had the House, the Senate and the White House.

They're going to basically say, as I think Marie said a few minutes, hey listen, you guys are in charge. And that argument might resonate. Are you concerned with that politically?

COLLINS: Well, here is what I hope politically if this does happen that Leader McConnell realizes it's time to get rid of the filibuster once and for all. Because again, we've done it now and the Supreme Court judges because of senator Schumer. I'll say thank you Senator Schumer for being such an obstructionist that we had no choice but get rid of the filibuster through Supreme Court judges.

Well, maybe here is another example why that rule of the Senate, it's not in the constitution. It's nothing more than an archaic rule that should be eliminated. Now then you could blame us. But when you need 60 votes in the Senate and it's Senator Schumer that's got to deliver.

This is a Schumer shutdown were it to occur --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

COLLINS: -- and I think we would absolutely remind the American public of that.

BARTIROMO: -- which is why the President is tweeting on this right now actually. He just tweeted on the shutdown saying this, "Government funding bill passed last night in the House of Representatives. Now Democrats are needed if it is to pass in the Senate. But they want illegal immigration and a weak border. Shutdown coming? We need more Republican victories in 2018."

So Congressman Collins -- How are you going to get more Republican victories in 2018 when you are sitting on the precipice of a government shutdown and the perception will be that Republicans are at fault?

COLLINS: Well, that is perception and we've got to make sure the reality - - the truth comes out and we are sitting now on the most historic tax reform in 31 years. And now worker after worker is going to see more money in their paycheck.

And that's the playbook we have is the fundamental tax reform, more money in workers' pockets, higher 401(k), balances, the economy rocking and rolling, and we're company after company increasing their starting wages. And we will make sure that anyone and everyone knows this is, if it happens, Schumer shutdown.

BRENBERG: But Congressman, you know, to that point, even if this looks like -- even if people think it is the Schumer shutdown, the problem is this news dominates headlines instead of the news we've seen over past few days with Apple and other companies.

To me the Republicans are going to lose with the shutdown either way because the good news story, and it's a great news story on tax cuts, just is not going to get through.

Frankly I think Democrats like that. I think that's why they are gunning for a shutdown here.

COLLINS: Oh, there's no doubt that Senator Schumer is looking -- but it's risky for him -- at the political outcomes here. And again, now that we passed it in the House, it is the Democrats we need in the Senate.

So we will have to see how this plays out. Both parties lose, America loses and that is what I'd be saying to Senator Schumer. Let's do what's right for America.

We should also remind all Americans, all essential services in the government will continue, our military and everyone else. And we're not going to do the little things that Obama did when we had the shutdown in '13 like make sure that he put blockades at the turnarounds in the parks and he closed the World War II Memorial where there is not even any employees there.

Barack Obama tried to inflict pain on America in the last shutdown. That is not the way Donald Trump -- President Trump operates.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

COLLINS: We would make this as easy as we could, a shutdown is not good for America but essential services will continue and I'm confident that under President Trump the World War II Memorial will be open.

HARF: Congressman, we definitely heard your message to Senator Schumer. That came across loud and clear. Do you also have a message for Senator McConnell and your Republican colleagues in the Senate some of whom have also said they are against voting for this? You know, you don't have Democrats on board but there are still a number of Republican holdouts. What is your message to your colleagues across the aisle here to get them on board?

COLLINS: Well, my message to Senator McConnell and the Republicans is get rid of the filibuster. Then you can blame us.

And you know, last night we were having to whip out many of our House Republicans to make sure we got the votes. So the fact that there are people that may be leaning yes or undecided in the Senate, we had that last night in the House. And we delivered.

And I'm sure that if there was no filibuster we would deliver in the Senate as well. So that's my message to Leader McConnell. Get rid of the filibuster.

BARTIROMO: Congressman -- let's talk about New York for a moment -- a knife to the Big Apple -- on New York State. Apparently New Yorkers are bearing the brunt of tax reform negatives most significantly the elimination of the SALT deduction -- that $10,000 federal property tax. And then what can be for New Yorkers who are struggling with tax reform fallout, tell us how you see it?

And then there's this. The cover story of the "New York Post" today, "Land of the Fee: look out Uber, state is pushing $11.50 toll just to go below 60th street". So we're going to have -- they are proposing putting tolls within New York City -- to go from uptown to downtown?

COLLINS: Sure. Well, first of all Maria -- 95 percent of New Yorkers are going to have a significant tax cut. Certainly up in my district in western New York, the Buffalo area it's probably 98 percent.

BARTIROMO: Right.

COLLINS: What we're hearing is Senator Schumer and King Andrew Cuomo fighting for the millionaires and the billionaires on Long Island, it's quite the juxtaposition as the Republicans are fighting for the working class, the middle class.

BARTIROMO: Right.

COLLINS: And we've got our supposedly progressive or actually progressive governor fighting for the millionaires but 95 percent, 98 percent of New Yorkers are going to see a -- basically a $2,000 a year increase.

BARTIROMO: Right. No, I'm aware of that. I'm aware of that -- Congressman. But you know, the elimination of the SALT deduction is going to mean higher taxes for some people.

COLLINS: Only the wealthy.

BARTIROMO: And Cuomo -- and the governor -- the governor has been complaining about it. Now he is threatening he needs to battle congestion, capitalize on a cash injection by placing tolls on New York City blocks.

COLLINS: Well, this governor has never seen a tax he didn't like or want to hike. And now he's going to look for new taxes that he can impose on us. And this is just --

BARTIROMO: Is there any shot that that passes, tolls within New York City?

COLLINS: Who knows? I mean with this governor he has -- he rules with an iron fist --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

COLLINS: -- and anyone and everyone knows because he controls all the economic development dollars in New York, you vote his way or you will pay a price.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Congressman let me switch gears real quick, get your take on this FISA frenzy -- the circulation of a confidential intelligence memo. It alleges surveillance abuses made by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act", sending shockwaves throughout Congress.

BRENBERG: So, these are not just the companies that you want to work for, they are the companies --

MARIE HARF, FORMER SPOKESPERSON U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT & FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes.

BRENBERG: -- you like their products, you like their marketing, you like their story, it's bigger than just who do you want to work - or maybe it doesn't have anything to do with who you want to --

O'KEEFE: And I --

BRENBERG: -- work with?

O'KEEFE: -- think it's rival executives, people that say, `hey, I would like my company to be as successful as these companies are,' you know, --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

O'KEEFE: -- everyone wants to be as successful as Apple.

Apple's number one for the 11th straight year, no --

BARTIROMO: Oh.

O'KEEFE: -- coincidence that their stocks up you know, 13 times over that period so --

BARTIROMO: Thirteen times and yesterday we spoke with Roger McNamee from Elevation Partners, a really astute investor in Technology, here's what he said about Apple; listen to this?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER MCNAMEE, CO-FOUNDER OF SILVER LAKE PARTNERS, MANAGING DIRECTOR & CO- FOUNDER, ELEVATION PARTNERS: I actually think Apple is a company everybody should pay attention to.

I work - admire Apple more than any company that's out there today and I think that they are the one check in our economy on Google, on Facebook. They have done some great things to protect consumers and importantly, I think they are undervalued even though it's the largest cap in the - the largest market cap of any stock in the world.

I think what they're doing is absolutely brilliant.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Isn't that interesting?

Even undervalued as - it's - and 13 times over?

O'KEEFE: Yes.

Yes, 13 times - 13-fold increase in 11 years, 900 billion-dollar marketing cap, I mean that's incredible,

They're - they're PE has tended to be lower than a lot of those other big tech companies over the last several years so you know, I - is everybody ready to go all in on Apple right now?

I don't know.

MCSHANE: So, Apple is in the news yesterday but GE is in the news yesterday --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BRENBERG: -- as well and --

BARTIROMO: Good point.

MCSHANE: -- you know, they were at the top of the - I mean (INAUDIBLE) look back and find that they were top of this list, how often is somebody at the top of the list, kind of a sign that, everybody loves them but the world is changing, don't expect them to stay there.

O'KEEFE: Well GE, it's interesting you mention that, I mean they were a perennial on the list, there were number seven last year, they dropped to number 30 this year and that was even before the latest stuff.

I mean, will - we'll see if they are on the list next year --

MCSHANE: Yes.

O'KEEFE: -- they're not going in the right direction, obviously their stock is down 45 percent, last year, it's kind of a sad --

BARTIROMO: They cut --

O'KEEFE: 's story.

BARTIROMO: -- the dividend, it is a sad --

O'KEEFE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- story. It's a 125-year-old company --

BRENBERG: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- but you made a really good point Marie in the commercial break saying, `you can't believe Southwest Airlines is still there --

HARF: I love it (ph).

BARTIROMO: -- and do other airlines vote for Southwest?

HARF: Right, I mean it's - it's shocking that an airline of that statue (ph) is that high above Facebook which Americans use constantly almost (ph) --

BRENBERG: Yes.

HARF: -- everyday.

O'KEEFE: Well as you were saying you know, they haven't made the headlines for the wrong reasons and you --

BARTIROMO: Sure.

O'KEEFE: -- know I think that they've operated so well through different oil price environments and the different operating environments and downturns you know, I think people just really, really, admire what they do.

BARTIROMO: Great list (ph).

Thank you, Brian.

We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Good Friday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, January 19th; your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RXN-7FT1-F12V-X2J6-00000-00Sì alle regole senza soffocare la grande rete2018-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisCULTURAPag. 25Sì alle regole senza soffocare la grande reteGianni Riotta

C'era una volta Big Oil, deprecato cartello delle sette compagnie petrolifere. Prima c'era stato Big Steel, lobby dell'acciaio, e poi Big Tobacco, i cinque mega, contestatissimi, brand delle sigarette. Ma chi avrebbe detto che anche l'industria digitale, che doveva guidarci per mano all'utopia della comunicazione diretta, all'Intelligenza Artificiale, alla Rete cui volevamo concedere il premio Nobel per la pace via Facebook, Google, Apple, Amazon, Twitter, finisse denigrata come Big Tech, totem monopolistico da multare, accusare, trascinare in giudizio?Ieri Facebook ha perso il 6% in Borsa, 30 miliardi di dollari (24 miliardi di euro) sfumati.

I mercati penalizzano il colosso di Mark Zuckerberg dopo le denunce dell'informatico Christopher Wylie che accusa l'azienda Cambridge Analytica di aver dragato illegalmente 50 milioni di profili di utenti FB, rivendendoli alla campagna elettorale di Trump, via lo stratega nazionalista Bannon e il magnate conservatore Mercer. I leader tecnologici si son illusi di essere salvatori dell'umanità, con Ray Kurzweil teorico dell'«era transumana», in cui ogni limite della nostra specie, fisico, etico, spirituale, verrà oltrepassato, fino all'immortalità e alle macchine pensanti pensiero. La rivoluzione transumana sarà innescata dalla «Singularity», il momento in cui l'Intelligenza Artificiale libererà l'Homo Sapiens dal giogo del lavoro, dai limiti economici, dalla gravità, materiale e morale. Contro questa arroganza, i Greci la chiamavano hybris, si levano i catastrofisti digitali, luddisti del web come gli artigiani inglesi che distruggevano i telai meccanici della rivoluzione industriale: Evgenj Morozov convinto che il mercato web distrugga la creatività, Franklin Foer sicuro che «i monopoli del tech vogliono plasmare l'umanità a propria immagine e somiglianza» e il geniale fisico Stephen Hawking, appena scomparso, ad ammonire che l'invenzione dell'Intelligenza Artificiale, maggiore scoperta umana, potrebbe esser l'ultima se le macchine ci faranno loro schiavi. Incuranti di queste profezie, miliardi di noi han continuato ad usare Facebook per comunicare la propria vita, Google per capire cosa accade nel rione e sul pianeta, Apple per darsi un'identità, Twitter, WhatsApp, Snapchat, Instagram per condividerla. In Russia e in Cina il web è controllato dallo Stato, nelle democrazie invece, tra privacy e mercato, si crea un vuoto dove spie, lobby occulte, Stati canaglia e seminatori di zizzanie digitali inquinano dibattito ed elezioni.Facebook ha ora guai pesanti. Il presidente del Parlamento Europeo Antonio Tajani twitta di «minaccia al funzionamento della democrazia», la Commissione Elettorale britannica cerca prove di manomissione dei dati personali nel voto per Brexit, il Bureau federale per la Protezione dei Consumatori e il ministro della Giustizia del Massachusetts indagano in America. La compagnia rischia negli Usa una multa fino a 40.000 dollari per ogni utente la cui privacy è stata violata, e il 25 maggio scatterà in Europa una rigidissima norma sulla privacy, General Data Protection Regulation (Gdpr), che imporrà sanzioni fino al 4% del fatturato in caso di intrusioni tipo quelle imputate a Facebook. Nel frattempo i giovani, stufi, lasciano il social media, quest'anno tre milioni di americani e inglesi sotto i 25 anni usciranno da Facebook, ormai «network di papà e mamma». La tecnologia e i social media non erano talismano magico ieri, non sono stregoneria perversa oggi. Non ci renderanno invulnerabili, né schiavi. Ogni rivoluzione, dopo il primo impatto, è stata regolata, ferrovie, energia, telefonia, con i monopoli onnipotenti seguiti da aziende capaci ancora di competere e innovare. Questa stagione si riapre nel digitale, ma gli interventi politici non dovranno in alcun modo ossificare quel che di meraviglioso e libero il web ci ha donato. Le regole non dovranno mai essere camicie di forza: pur colma di buone intenzioni, per esempio, la Gdpr europea di protezione della privacy di maggio rischia di danneggiare, almeno nella prima fase, la sicurezza, l'antiterrorismo, la lotta alle truffe e allo spam online, anticipa l'esperto di cybersecurity Brian Krebs. Difendere l'Albero della Conoscenza nell'Eden digitale, scacciando il Serpente della disinformazione, ecco la vera missione.Facebook riotta.itBY NC ND ALCUNI DIRITTI RISERVATI

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5DJ7-5W81-F05M-K4KC-00000-00Sick of sleazy, spammy content on otherwise reputable websites? Here's an idea from inside the industry2014-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisSick of sleazy, spammy content on otherwise reputable websites? Here's an idea from inside the industryBen Fischer

The content-marketing companies that deliver online ads and news stories based on your own click habits are at a crossroads. Business appears to be booming for the bigger startups in the "content recommendation" space, and Yahoo is   joining the fray too.

But at the same time, regular Joes and influential tech leaders say they're tired of sleazy, irrelevant ads appearing on substantive sites, or nonsense fluff passed off as a serious page.

Get breaking business news delivered to your inbox. Sign up for our free newsletter .

In response, the industry is now competing on quality. Outbrain says it internally screens for low-quality ads before they're available on the platform; Taboola lets readers downvote unpleasant ads, and gives publishers the chance to eliminate bad ones too. Smaller competitor nRelate, an InteractiveCorp. (NASDAQ: IACI) subsidiary, recently launched its own plan: A full publisher dashboard that provides a series of ways to filter, pick and choose which ads are eligible to be served by the software, and weigh revenue against strategic brand issues.

Unless the whole landscape gets better at balancing quality and revenue, nRelate CEO Neil Mody thinks the entire concept is jeopardy. I caught up with him in an email exchange this week.

NYBJ: Content recommendation is pretty unpopular with readers, but large tech companies are talking about moving into the business. How do you explain the surge in competition?

Mody: On one hand, content recommendation is actually very popular and that's why large tech companies are getting involved. On the other, readers are starting to voice their lack of appreciation for the types and quality of recommendations they're seeing. Focusing in on why large tech companies are getting involved, to be perfectly honest, there's a lot of money in play. Like anyone, the big tech companies are always looking for new ways to branch out their offerings and create new revenue channels.

I'm actually encouraged by the move of some of the bigger companies into content recommendations for two reasons. First, it indicates that there's still plenty of opportunity for growth in the space and that it hasn't succumbed to total banner blindness ( the notion some readers find banner ads so ubiquitous and unwanted that they don't notice them anymore -- editor). Secondly, new competition forces us all to get better and come up with new products and solutions that are attractive to publishers, which is what we're focused on at nRelate.

NYBJ: You built nControl, which gives publishers more control over what gets recommended and doesn't. Why is that the answer?

Mody: Let's first step back and clearly define the problem. nControl is about creating transparency and providing publishers with an alternative to being left in the dark about what sponsored content shows up on their site. nControl isn't our attempt to police content quality , but rather to let publishers decide what ads fit with their editorial voice and are most relevant. Some publishers may want celebrity-focused content recommendations. Others that run tech or serious news stories might not want a girl in a bikini next to their articles. Either way, publishers should ultimately control this.

nControl starts by showing publishers the pool of every possible ad unit that may show up on their site. From there, publishers can make decisions about what ads they don't want to show up and block them accordingly. Publishers can decide to show editorial content, advertorial, or a mix of both. nControl even allows publishers to view and block content by category (e.g. travel, pets, sports, real estate) or keywords (e.g . Bieber, Kardashian). nControl shows publishers exactly how much they earn from each advertiser , and the projected changes to those earnings depending on content they decide to block or allow.

NYBJ: Everybody wants quality ads. But publishers need revenue. Are they losing anything in the long-term by maximizing their revenue in the short term? If so, what is the trade off?

Mody: Just as we don't aim to be the arbiters of content quality, we want publishers to make decisions about how they balance the content they allow on their site with their own revenue objectives. There are some publishers - especially those in the blogosphere - that only use content recommendations to drive traffic to their own internal content. Others have much more aggressive revenue goals with how they use content recommendations. Neither is inherently bad. That said, we do believe focusing too much on short-term revenues does carry with it potential risks for many publishers.

The trade off here can be damage to a publisher's brand image. Many media brands have spent years and even decades building and maintaining a certain reputation. Maximizing short-term revenue by promoting the kinds of ads and content that get clicks no matter where they are (think sex and fear) , but are completely off the mark , can erode reader trust and a publisher's credibility. Publishers need to decide on the balance, but if they don't even know what ads are running on their site to begin with, they could unknowingly be trading reader trust and credibility for short-term clicks.

Q: What's at risk for the entire concept of content recommendation? You want to find some happy medium that keeps a revenue stream alive while cracking down on the worst content. If you or the rest of the industry isn't successful, what happens?

Mody: I mentioned "banner blindness" earlier, and the belief that content recommendations are going down the same path. Some claim we're already there. This is one unfortunate risk that all of us in the space face if ad tech companies like us, along with publishers , don't succeed in cleaning up the space. Content relevance is one thing, but there are other issues at stake such as content disclosure. When it comes to disclosing sponsored content units, external regulatory agencies have already become involved. Trying to play a cat-and-mouse game when it comes to disclosure will only lead to more regulation and scrutiny.

I think we're definitely at a crossroads in the content recommendation landscape. At nRelate, we believe a happy medium is still possible when it comes to keeping sponsored content transparent, relevant and properly disclose, while remaining a viable source of revenue. The alternative is that it becomes so bad it no longer works - and then everyone loses. We think there's still a lot of promise in content recommendations as part of the larger native advertising mix. And when done well, [it] can benefit publishers, ad-tech companies and readers alike.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5P73-NWM1-JBHT-D0KC-00000-00Sides drawn on net neutrality rollback plan2017-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisSides drawn on net neutrality rollback planRyan DeffenbaughPurchaseFULL TEXT

The Federal Communications Commission is considering rolling back net neutrality regulations approved in 2015 under President Barack Obama. If it does, there will likely be implications for business in Westchester, according to Jonathan H. Hill, dean of the Seidenberg School of Computer Science and Information Systems at Pace University.

"Westchester is a really important tech hub, in health care R&I), telemedicine, financial technology, even the startup scene," Hill said. "Westchester is getting to be a really exciting place. And all of those businesses thrive on open access to the internet."

Net neutrality refers broadly to a series of regulations meant to ensure all internet traffic is treated equally. The 2015 regulations prevent internet service providers from selling speedier internet access, known as "fast lanes," to certain companies over others.

FCC Chairman Ajit Pai wants to repeal those net neutrality rules, which classified internet service providers as utilities. The FCC in May voted 2-1 to advance that plan. The commission is seeking public input on the matter and has already received more than 9 million comments.

The original regulations are meant to prevent broadband providers from charging more for certain websites and internet services or blocking websites that use a lot of bandwidth and are deemed by providers to be too demanding.

Major broadband providers such as AT&T and Comcast have argued that the regulations discourage investment in their networks.

Talk of rolling back net neutrality has sparked protest from major technology companies, including Google, Facebook, Netflix and Amazon. The companies led a "day of action" against the rollback on July 12. Netflix ran a banner on its homepage reading "Protect Internet Freedom. Defend Net Neutrality. Take Action." Twitter promoted the hashtag "#netneutrality" on its homepage, while Amazon ran a homepage ad that read "Net Neutrality? Learn more."

"If a service provider can block you from seeing certain content or can make you pay extra for it, that hurts all of us and we should have rules against it," Facebook CEO and co-founder Mark Zuckerberg wrote in a post on July 12.

Any rollback of net neutrality regulations is likely to be felt by individual users, according to Hill.

"You will begin to see this kind of tiered pricing, with internet providers trying to squeeze people to pay a higher rate for a better-quality internet experience," Hill said. "If you are someone who works from home a great deal, expect to pay more."

Those so-called fast lanes could be particularly concerning for small tech startups, according to Joel Felber, an attorney specializing in computer technology and intellectual property law at Leason Ellis in White Plains.

"If you are a small video provider, for example, and you are unable to cut a deal with a major internet service provider, or perhaps the only internet service provider that provides broadband, then you will have a very difficult time competing," Felber said.

Felber said another issue is a lack of competition among the providers. He said there are large swaths of the country that only have one or two broadband providers, if there are any offerings at that speed at all.

Westchester compares favorably with much of the country in that regard, he said.

"We're not somewhere with dial-up as the only option, which is happening for many, many people," Felber said. "It doesn't mean it's a good situation, it's still limited to a few providers, but it's better than other areas. That's important to remember in terms of startups, opportunities."

The Westchester County Association is leading an effort intended to improve upon the county's broadband infrastructure. The business group is working with the mayors of Yonkers, Mount Vernon, White Plains and New Rochelle to try to launch a network of gigabit broadband, which has download speeds about 20 times faster than basic broadband.

Joan McDonald, a former commissioner of the state Department of Transportation and now an adviser to the Westchester County Association, said it's unclear how changes to the net neutrality regulations could affect that plan.

"Right now, it doesn't appear to" have any effect, she said. "But that could change. This is an industry that is evolving quickly, both from a tech standpoint and a governance standpoint."

The FCC will seek comments from the public on the matter until mid-August.

"Certainly this administration and this Congress are very pro rolling it back," Hill said. "I think a lot of the big tech money remains strongly pro net neutrality, so it will be very, very interesting to see."

urn:contentItem:5YVH-P471-JDH1-C03C-00000-00Sidewalk Labs pulls out of Toronto's Quayside project, blaming COVID-192020-05-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 0Sidewalk Labs pulls out of Toronto's Quayside project, blaming COVID-19David Rider Donovan Vincent

COVID-19 is being blamed for the surprise end to Sidewalk Labs' controversial plan to create a high-tech district on Toronto's waterfront - a move that has some civic backers disappointed, while others see it as a chance to create a more citizen-directed development on the site in the future.

The Manhattan-based sister company of tech giant Google made the news public Thursday in a blog post from Sidewalk Labs chief executive Dan Doctoroff. He blamed the global economic upheaval caused by the pandemic and the resulting uncertainty over Toronto's real estate market.

" In October 2017, Sidewalk Labs and Waterfront Toronto set out to plan a shared vision for Quayside, a fundamentally more sustainable and affordable community resulting from innovations in technology and urban design," Doctoroff wrote.

"So it is with great personal sadness and disappointment that Sidewalk Labs will no longer pursue the Quayside project," he wrote.

"But as unprecedented economic uncertainty has set in around the world and in the Toronto real estate market, it has become too difficult to make the 12-acre project financially viable without sacrificing core parts of the plan we had developed together with Waterfront Toronto to build a truly inclusive, sustainable community," he added.

"And so, after a great deal of deliberation, we concluded that it no longer made sense to proceed with the Quayside project, and let Waterfront Toronto know yesterday."

Sidewalk Labs will continue working on urban innovation, he wrote, calling it "difficult" to walk away from attempts to reach a final development deal.

"Toronto is one of the world's great centres of technological innovation, and nothing about this decision will in any way diminish that," he said.

Keerthana Rang, a spokesperson for Sidewalk Labs said the firm made the decision, then contacted Alphabet, the parent company of Sidewalk Labs and Google on Tuesday.

Sidewalk Labs will maintain its head office at Parliament Street and Lakeshore Boulevard for now and attempt to redeploy the 30 staffers that work there.

Waterfront Toronto, a tri-government agency that is steward of Toronto's waterfront lands put out the original request for proposals to develop the 12-acre site in March 2017. Sidewalk Labs won that bid the following October.

The project, which was to be a mainly residential development with commercial components, became highly controversial, in large part over the collection of data on everything from foot traffic through the community, to the garbage disposal and energy use of residents, weather conditions and more.

But after a public outcry over privacy and data concerns, Sidewalk Labs agreed to significant concessions, including allowing Waterfront Toronto to be responsible for oversight of how the data collected at Quayside would be stored and managed.

Sidewalk Labs was also forced to revert to the original 4.8-hectare footprint last fall after backlash over its proposal to help develop as much as 77 hectares of the Portlands.

Waterfront Toronto chair Steve Diamond said he's disappointed the project fell through, but not surprised by the news of Sidewalk Labs leaving town.

"When you look at the deal, this goes back three years. It was really planned and modelled in a pre-COVID environment," said Diamond.

"Even then, apart from the financial considerations, the complexity of the project and regulatory changes - the contemplation of construction of a tall timber factory (to construct wood framed buildings at Quayside), these are all enormous undertakings. And if you look around the world today, many existing plans have been altered or abandoned based on these (COVID-19) circumstances."

Diamond suggested the departure of Sidwalk Labs, though unfortunate, presents new opportunities around what to do with the 12 acres and more on the eastern waterfront.

"Is a smart city the best objective now for the use of these lands? Or, for example, should we be concentrating on innovation but in a different sense - the opportunity to provide more affordable rental and home ownership opportunities? The opportunity to create new and dynamic public open spaces? The opportunity to create, for example, new ways to help small businesses and retailers?"

Diamond, who is a real estate developer, went on to say that Thursday's news isn't a set back for the city.

"Toronto is an international city people want to invest in," he said.

Waterfront Toronto spokesperson Andrew Tumilty said Thursday the agency spent $16 million over the past three years, less than three per cent of the appraised value of the Quayside land.

Tumilty said Waterfront Toronto views That money as an "investment" in what will one day deliver innovative solutions on the eastern waterfront.

Sidewalk has spent more than $50 million (U.S.) on the Quayside project.

Shauna Brail, director and associate professor in U of T's urban studies program, voiced concern about Sidewalk Labs' decision.

"There will be many who say that today's decision is a win for Toronto. I disagree. As a global city, we need to build relationships and partnerships that bring people, new ideas, and investments to Toronto.

"We won't know the full impact of this decision for some time, however it's safe to say that the implications go well beyond the 12 acres on our waterfront," she added.

"Regardless of whether or not one agreed with their decision to partner with Sidewalk Labs, Waterfront Toronto will be faced with rebuilding trust - with communities, governments and industry."

Matti Siemiatycki, an associate professor in U of T's geography and planning department said the key now is for Waterfront Toronto to assert itself as the lead planner for that area.

"Where the Sidewalk Labs project ran into trouble in the community, is it was unclear who was leading. Was it Waterfront Toronto and the city or Sidewalk Labs bringing forward their ideas of what a significant portion of the city should look like?" Siemiatycki said.

"Coming out of this project, we've learned residents want our civic officials as the guardians of the public interests to be the ones who are setting the vision and working with citizens and residents to come up with that collectively."

Toronto Mayor John Tory said Thursday that he'll push Waterfront Toronto to help create a new Quayside that will "create new jobs and economic development opportunities, a carbon-neutral neighbourhood with more housing including affordable housing units, and better transportation and sustainability features."

Asked how land values figured into the pullout, Tory said the city had to protect Torontonians' interests in allocating to Sidewalk Labs "one of the most valuable pieces of real estate in the city.

"That was clearly an issue," among other factors in the deal's collapse, Tory said.

"The process certainly got off to a rocky start in terms of process and how the (partnership) was governed," and that might have plagued the project all the way through, he added.

Ontario Premier Doug Ford called Sidewalk's decision unfortunate, but added that: "Now there's an opportunity for other people to do something spectacular on the Toronto waterfront and we look forward to sitting down with the mayor and getting his thoughts," he said, praising Toronto's developers and architects.

The Toronto Region Board of Trade, a strong supporter of Sidewalk Labs' role in the Quayside project, called the pullout "not unexpected.

"The world has changed a lot since the outbreak of COVID, which impacts capacity to take on really ambitious projects like this," said Janet De Silva, the board's chief executive.

De Silva predicted that the post-pandemic era will see the economy rebuilt to reflect health concerns, so restarting waterfront innovation presents an opportunity.

Waterfront Toronto chose Sidewalk Labs as its preferred development partner for Quayside, a former industrial site at Parliament Street and Queens Quay, with fanfare and international headlines.

Organized opposition, including a group called #BlockSidewalk, urged Waterfront Toronto to end long and laboured negotiations to reach final agreement on Quayside that saw deadline after deadline pushed back.

"This is huge. We are sending a message to Silicon Valley on behalf of all those around the world who are fighting big tech in their cities," Julie Beddoes, one of the organizers with #BlockSidewalk said in a statement Thursday.

With files from Robert Benzie

David Rider is the Star's City Hall bureau chief and a reporter covering city hall and municipal politics. Follow him on Twitter: @dmrider

Donovan Vincent is a housing reporter based in Toronto. Follow him on Twitter: @donovanvincent

urn:contentItem:60KM-S661-F0PT-C00G-00000-00'Significant tailwinds' can sustain FAANG outperformance despite growing regulation risk2020-08-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexis'Significant tailwinds' can sustain FAANG outperformance despite growing regulation riskdavid.brenchley@incisivemedia.com(David Brenchley)

The recent US earnings season saw the FAANG cohort of the stockmarket post expectation-beating results.

Apple, Amazon, Alphabet and Facebook collectively added around $200bn to their market values after reporting on the same day.

Facebook posted its slowest revenue growth since its IPO but still added $42.6bn to its value, while Alphabet added $7.6bn despite posting its first revenue decline ever.

Legg Mason's Osmani shuns FAANGs to outperform US market

Investment director at Aberdeen Standard Investments Karolina Noculak said that this does not mean Google's parent company should be considered "a weak stock", but "quite the opposite".

She explained: "When we look at the declines in the advertising sector, compared to Alphabet's, the company saw only a 2% revenue decline versus the industry down 20%. Alphabet did very, very well."

"All of these companies had really strong quarters and all exceeded expectations. Some of them grew the earnings so enormously that it was not in any of the analyst projections, not even on the bullish end of the expectations spectrum. So really a remarkable, remarkable quarter."

Manager of Sarasin & Partners' Digital Opportunities fund Josh Sambrook-Smith observed that the differential in both firms' commercial performance reflected "the type of advertising they sell".

Sambrook-Smith suggested advertisers in Q2 seemed to have reduced their spending on search, as demand was weaker, which led Google to see a decline in revenue growth.

That reduction in search spend benefited Facebook, whose adverts are more versatile, as firms "clearly felt placing their advertising dollars higher up the funnel was a better way to invest their budgets".

Forget the FAANGs - the top under-the-radar tech opportunities

This, said Raj Shant, portfolio specialist at Jennison Associates, shows investors must look "under the hood of the big tech companies and not discriminate between the business models".

"There are very real differences in quality and sustainability of the prodigious revenues and cash flows they are currently generating," he explained.

"While it is tempting to see big tech as one homogeneous entity, it is becoming increasingly imperative to appreciate this is far from the truth."

With the likes of Facebook, Google and their competitors more exposed to advertising revenues that are likely to become increasingly cyclically exposed, "other business models based on subscription revenues are likely to prove far more enduring", Shant reasoned.

"Similarly, e-commerce penetration may have leapt in recent quarters, but there is still a lot of the retail sales that could still migrate online.

"The migration to cloud-based services may also have accelerated sharply during the pandemic but could still have a long runway as corporates have seen the immense convenience and value moving functions onto the cloud can offer."

Artemis US equities head Weldon: Facebook break-up would boost value

While sentiment remains positive on big tech, with Noculak noting "significant tailwinds" from a continued shifting or spending from offline to online, there are risks, too, with regulation front and centre.

Four of the cohort of big tech companies - Facebook, Google, Amazon and Alphabet - were accused of being "too powerful" and "engaged in behaviour that is anti-competitive" by the US House Antitrust Subcommittee.

The committee argued that some of these entities "need to be broken up", while "all need to be properly regulated".

Investors will eagerly await a report set to be published later this year that could recommend legislative changes. "These are super profitable companies that have built almost monopolistic positions, are now increasingly being challenged by regulators," said Noculak.

The investment director countered that the risk of regulation is unlikely to be a short-term consideration, "as there are more urgent things to deal with in this Covid world". However, as a sector with "very, very low regulation compared to other parts of the economy", it is "a longer term risk that can lead to a cap on future profits".

Polar Capital's Rogoff: Covid-19 will alter people's behaviours forever

But senior markets economist at Capital Economics Oliver Jones noted the antitrust regime, under both Republican and Democratic leadership, has become "less and less stringent" since the 1980s.

"This suggests to us that a really significant regulatory push against, or break-up of, the big tech firms is highly unlikely in the absence of major political change," said Jones.

Alan Tu, portfolio manager of the T. Rowe Price Global Technology Equity fund, accepted regulators, politicians and judges are likely to come to different conclusions on the issue and urged investors to "pay attention as the debate continues".

However, he questioned whether these dominant firms are, actually, "stifling innovation and harming the consumer".

Tu believes the opposite may be true. "The 'Amazon effect' has brought down retail prices, and popular services such as Google Maps or Instagram are free," he reasoned.

"Appreciation for the services provided by the platform companies during the pandemic has also changed the tone of the conversation, at least temporarily."

Others have drawn parallels with 2020's hearings and the monopolisation case brought agains Microsoft in the late 1990s and early 2000s, when regulators contemplated breaking the firm up, but decided instead to impose conduct remedies demanding the firm to stop behaving badly, Sarasin's Sambrook-Smith recalled.

That case, noted former assistant attorney general Bill Baer in a recent blog post, took more than three years from initial filing to settlement.

"There is no reason to expect that antitrust actions against Google or others will move more rapidly than that one did, or that the courts will be sympathetic to a monopolisation case," Baer said.

As Sambrook-Smith added that by the time Microsoft was sanctioned, one could argue "the horse had already bolted", with "Microsoft still to this day remaining an effective monopoly in the PC market".

"The Microsoft case doesn't exactly imply apocalypse for the FAANGS," Sambrook-Smith continued. "Perhaps just some severe hand slapping and fines?

"In any case, a serious economic evaluation of these companies market power certainly doesn't suggest they are dominant. Amazon's share of e-commerce is 45% but its share of US retail spending is less than 10%. Is that really enough to pursue a monopoly suit?"

Baillie Gifford's Paice: The 'game-changers' that will drive returns for the next decade

In the meantime, Noculak expects trends that are supportive of the big tech firms to continue, while the firms' balance sheets "remain rock solid".

"I wouldn't worry about a profitability collapse in the near term despite those strategic horizon risks. To actually see something that makes you abandon this sector completely, it would have to be quite game changing."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VP4-DR11-JCJY-G0JX-00000-00Signs that Google sees EU fines as more than just operating expenses2019-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:04ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:2Signs that Google sees EU fines as more than just operating expensesSimon Duke

The spectre of the European elections has added a frisson to Westminster's already tortured Brexit deliberations. In Brussels, the poll has had a similar effect.

After the votes are counted in May and MEPs sworn in, there will be a clear-out at the European Commission. Department heads are rushing to complete projects before the new commissioners are appointed in the summer.

Today, Europe's anti-trust watchdog closed the book on its most significant investigation. Margarethe Vestager, the European Commission's competition chief, fined Google (EURO)1.5 billion for crushing rivals in internet search advertising. It is the third (EURO)1bn-plus sanction that she has meted out to the US giant since 2016.

The latest case concerns Google's relations with publishers, such as newspaper websites and blogs. Many embed the Google search bar on their sites, and receive a share of the income from related adverts. Google placed onerous restrictions on where publishers could place competing ads, blocking the display of results from rival online search advertisers, which put competitors such as Yahoo and Microsoft at a disadvantage. Google put an end to the practices in 2016, but only after Ms Vestager launched her inquiry.

The fine comes months after she levied a record (EURO)4.3 billion penalty on Google for abusing its dominant position in mobile phone software to crush competing search and mapping apps. In 2016, Ms Vestager sanctioned Google for doctoring search results to favour its own shopping services. The Silicon Valley tech giant is challenging the first two rulings and is expected to fight the commission's latest fine.

The connective tissue in all three cases is internet search, where the company controls about 90 per cent of the market. Google has flouted anti-trust rules by using this dominant position as a battering ram to break into new markets and squash putative rivals.

The commission is to be applauded for holding Google to account, in contrast to the inaction of America's supine competition authority. The question is whether Ms Vestager has achieved her aim of injecting more competition into Europe's digital economy. The answer, at this point, must be "no".

Rivals have failed to establish a foothold in Europe. Despite Ms Vestager's efforts, Google remains in a lucrative feedback loop. The more we use its search engine, the more data it reaps and the fatter profits it can earn from targeted adverts. The fines have barely left a scratch on Google's carapace. The (EURO)8.25 billion of EU penalties is the equivalent of just over three months of after-tax earnings. Alphabet, Google's parent, has a separate reporting line in its accounts, called "European Commission fines", suggesting it views the sanctions as a mere business expense.

On another level, Vestager's campaign has been a success. She has placed the dominance of big tech on the regulatory agenda. The US Federal Trade Commission, dropped an investigation into Google's dominance of internet search in 2013. The tide, however, has turned. Elizabeth Warren, a Presidential hopeful, is among a number of Democrats calling for a break-up of the search giant.

The EU sanctions are also forcing Google to modify its behaviour. Hours before the EU fine was announced, Google said that it would invite Android users in Europe to choose which browsers and search apps they would like to use, instead of crowbarring its own apps on to their home screen.

It is often said that it is impossible for monopolies to endure in the fast-growing technology markets. I'm not so sure. The concentration of personal data in the hands of a small number of companies could give them a decisive lead in new technologies, such as AI. Liberating this data should be the mission of Ms Vestager's successor.

Simon Duke is Technology Business Editor of The Times
